intro: Ocotea commutata, commonly known as the West Indian cinnamon or mountain cinnamon, is a small evergreen tree native to the Caribbean and parts of Central America. It belongs to the Lauraceae family, which includes other aromatic plants like laurel and cinnamon. The plant is characterized by its glossy, elliptical leaves and small, fragrant flowers that bloom in clusters. Its bark and leaves contain essential oils, contributing to its use in traditional medicine and as a source of aromatic compounds. Ocotea commutata thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in tropical rainforests.
